plist.p: Well good morning, everyone and welcome to our Half Year Results Presentation. I'm Alison Cooper, Chief Executive of Imperial; and with me is Bob Dyrbus, our Finance Director; and other members of the Senior Imperial team, including Matthew Phillips, who'll be appointed to Board as Corporate Affairs Director in June. I'm pleased Matthew's joining the Board, and his appointment reflects the important of Corporate Affairs to our sales growth strategy. After a brief overview of our first half performance, the team will take any questions.

Our strategy continues to deliver sustainable returns to our shareholders and we remain focused on realizing the potential of our assets. We maximize shareholder returns by driving sales, generating high-margin profit and using our cash to reward investors and support the development of the business. It's a growth model that continues to create significant value for our shareholders.

The four sales growth drivers are central to our success, and I'll be talking more about them later. Our focus on driving growth through our unique total tobacco portfolio whilst effectively managing costs and cash has delivered a number of highlights in first half. And the sales momentum we're generating has been reflected in the strong performance in the second quarter, with tobacco net revenues up 8% against the same period last year.
We delivered good first half growth from our key strategic brands, Davidoff, Gauloises Blonde, West and JPS, with combined stick equivalent volumes up 5% and brand net revenues up 12%.

Fine cut tobacco volumes declined 1%, driven by market weakness in Poland. Excluding Poland, our volumes were up 3%. We improved volumes of our luxury Cuban cigars by 3% and revenues by 8%, with strong growth in emerging markets. And we again delivered excellent results in smokeless, improving snus volumes by 74%.
On a constant currency basis, our portfolio gains resulted in growth in both tobacco net revenues and adjusted operating profit of 3.3%.

We continue to invest in the business to build sustainable revenue growth whilst maintaining strong tobacco adjusted operating margins at around 43%. Adjusted earnings per share rose 5.1%, we increased the interim dividend by 13% and intend to continue growing annual dividend ahead of adjusted earnings per share growth. In addition, we completed the £500 million share buyback announced this time last year. And the buyback will continue at this annualized rate going forward.

On a half yearly basis, stick equivalent volumes were down 4%. The first quarter was challenging due to a number of specific external factors, which clouded our true achievements. And looking at the second quarter figures gives you a much better insight into the sales momentum we're generating. We delivered a strong performance with volumes down just 1% and tobacco net revenues up 8%, and that's despite the impact of the Syria sanctions, which we're still lapping. While second quarter growth reflects the success of our key strategic brands, with combined stick equivalent volumes up 6% and revenues up 15% against the same period last year, a very pleasing performance and we'll be building on this sales momentum in the remainder of the year.

So that's an overview of what we've achieved. I want to now focus on the how. How we're realizing the potential of our assets to drive sales growth and deliver high quality sustainable earnings growth.

We have a winning mindset, a best-in-class reputation for managing costs and industry-leading margins. And we're very focused on delivering sales excellence across the business through our four sales growth drivers. These are portfolio management, innovation, customer engagements and pricing. Applying consumer and customer insights across the four growth drivers is key to the work we're doing to drive sustainable sales growth. We're enhancing our expertise in all these areas and we're very pleased with the results.

Let's start by looking at portfolio management. It is about capitalizing on our portfolio strength, realizing the potential of total tobacco to maximize our share of consumers and consumption, reaching more consumers on more occasions.

We've been very successful in achieving this with Davidoff, generating strong sales growth in emerging markets where disposable incomes and consumer preferences for luxury brands are increasing. Half-year volumes were up 2% with further gains in Asia and the Middle East, and we grew second quarter volumes by 5%, reflecting the brand's positive momentum.

In Eastern Europe, we put Davidoff into profitable high-growth segments such as king-size, super slims and queen size, significantly increasing our volumes for these formats. Davidoff growth was also strong in Asia Pacific where brand volumes were up 11%. And there's much more to come. Davidoff has huge potential, and we're currently finalizing a number of key initiatives to fuel further growth in the second half and into next year.

Gauloises Blonde is our largest brand, with annual stick equivalent volumes of around £30 billion. It's a brand that's well-positioned in the EU and growing fast in Africa and the Middle East. The success of Gauloises Blonde is driven by its iconic branding, emphasizing freedom and joie de vivre. We're currently rolling out a new global campaign called Light Up Your Life which highlights the brand's sense of free spirit.

These initiatives are designed to build on what was a great first half performance from Gauloises Blonde. Volumes were up 11%, driven by strong gains in Africa and the Middle East where volumes increased by 20%. We've also extended the franchise with Gauloises Tactil, a new cigarette blend in an innovative GlideTec pack. It's just been launched in France and the initial response has been excellent.

Overall volumes of West were flat, but we're achieving in numerous emerging markets in Eastern Europe and Asia, with Taiwan up 35% and further growth in Russia and the Ukraine. Consumer demand for innovation remains strong in Eastern Europe. The launch of queen-sized West compact in Ukraine and West Duo with a crushball filter in Russia is supporting our ability to capitalize on these growing trends.

JPS has been a star performer for several years. By making JPS increasingly relevant to value-seeking consumers and creating a total tobacco brand franchise, we've transformed its performance. Annual volumes reached 25 billion stick equivalents in the year to March and we continue to build on the JPS success story. We increased volumes by over 4% in the first half, achieving growth in a number of markets with strong results in the UK and Australia. And there's further untapped potential in JPS. We recently completed a major rejuvenation project aimed at reinforcing the brand's credentials.

We're world leaders in fine cut, and we've been reinforcing this position by strategically managing share and profits to maximize returns. Overall volumes were down, due to a weaker market in Poland compounded by destocking where we increased our share. We're focused on driving profitable growth in the make-your-own category in a number of markets through JPS, Ducados and News. Our leadership in fine cut tobacco is supported by our ongoing success in papers and tubes where volumes were up 5% and 10% respectively in the first half.

We delivered another strong performance with our luxury Habanos cigars, particularly in emerging markets. Growth is being supported by limited editions, such as the Cohiba Behike line. We increased overall volumes by 3% and sales were up by 8%, with emerging market volumes up 12% and sales climbing 17% as a result of excellent gains in China, Russia and the Middle East.

And our Smokeless business continues to go from strength to strength in Scandinavia, where we developed a dynamic snus portfolio that's in tune with what consumers want. The portfolio is well-placed to reach more consumers on more occasions, with a strong presence in both premium and value. The new factory is enabling us to keep pace with the growing demand for our brands. In the first half, we improved volumes by an impressive 74%, and increased market shares in Sweden and Norway. And we further strengthened our position in Sweden by launching a new brand to compete in the value segment. Smålands Snus is named after the region where our factory is based and will further enhance our ability to maximize growth opportunities.

I gave a flavor of our innovation work earlier. It's an important driver of growth and we're making great strides in building a bigger pipeline of scalable innovations based on consumer insights. These consumer-led innovations are expanding our total tobacco portfolio. They're focused on giving consumers what they want and we're applying innovation to brands, products and markets in a way that will be margin-accretive. Pack innovations provide smokers with choice and reinforce brand differentiation. Branded tobacco packaging enables smokers to distinguish one brand from another, which drives effective competition between tobacco companies.

Through GlideTec, we've developed some industry-leading innovation built around consumer insights into the sociability of smoking. It's an innovation that strengthened Lambert & Butler's performance in the UK and we expect Tactil to do the same for Gauloises in France and Fortuna GlideTec to deliver similar results in Spain, following its launch last week.

Capacity investment is supporting GlideTec's international rollout with a number of other brand and market launches to follow. Setting the pace for innovation and being first to market is important and we're also focused on gaining share in high-growth segments and I highlighted some of these to you earlier. Here, you can see some other examples.

We've been active with crushball filter technology. West Duo has also been launched in Russia and Poland and we have a Fortuna version in France. Lambert & Butler Fresh Burst has just gone into the UK and there will be further crushball launches in other markets. We're also introducing queen size variants across many territories, including the current launch of L&B Profile in the UK. More initiatives are underway as we continue to focus on building a pipeline of fewer, bigger, better innovations that are scalable and will deliver high returns.

Customer engagement is about maximizing the availability and advocacy of our brands and products at the point of sale, leveraging our strong retailer partnerships to grow our share of consumers and consumption. We have a great reputation for customer engagement, and we're focused on enhancing our expertise in this area even further.

Customer engagement is a key focus area across our markets and it's particularly important in product display brand environments. We've made great strides in Australia, where our strong trade relationship have supported excellent share and volume gains. In the UK, we've been working with large retailers in the run up to the first stage of display restrictions, which came into effect last month.

We've also extended our UK sales force coverage and are increasing the frequency of our visits to independent retailers, reducing their working capital requirements and rewarding availability and advocacy. This activity is strengthening our position in the UK and is a key element to get consumer traction with innovations such as Lambert & Butler GlideTec, Profile and Fresh Burst.

The fourth sales growth driver is pricing, maximizing revenue growth by taking a strategic approach to pricing opportunities by brand, pack size and sales channel. This is about detailed price analysis and modeling across our footprint, as well as further enhancing our approach to engagement with authorities on excise matters.

Our pricing strategy for the Fortuna brand franchise in Spain is a good example of how we're applying this thinking. We offer consumers choice and value through differentiated Fortuna variants. And when we raised our prices last July, we positioned the Fortuna family at various price points to reach a broader range of consumers. This has helped us get Fortuna back on track, on a growth trend and its brand share is driving higher. We're implementing the same strategy in other markets, focused on maximizing share and revenue growth.

From a group perspective, we've already achieved over 80% of our pricing assumptions for this financial year. Applying all four sales growth drivers across our footprint is key to building sustainable sales and is delivering positive results across our regions.

This slide shows the recent upward trend of our cigarette and fine-cut tobacco shares. In the EU, we continue to focus on balancing share and profit to maximize returns. Some shares have been under pressure, but we're addressing this through the growth drivers. We generated positive results in our cigarette and fine-cut tobacco shares in our most of our major markets in the second quarter compared the first quarter of this year. That includes Spain, the UK, Germany and France.

Outside the EU, our U.S. share has been under pressure in what remains a very competitive market, while in our rest of the world region, there's growth in value and premium above product. We're capitalizing on key consumer growth segments through the success of our key strategic brands and our strong portfolio of local and regional brands, achieving particularly good results in Asia Pacific and Africa and the Middle East. This reflects the strong second quarter momentum we generated across our regions, and we'll be building on this in the second half.
And I hand you over to Bob to take you through the financials.

Thanks, Alison, and good morning, everyone. I'll start with an overview of the results. This table includes the reconciliation between reported and constant currency numbers. I'll be focusing on constant currency-adjusted numbers for all of my comments. Results have been adjusted and presented on our usual basis, with details in the appendices.

Tobacco net revenues were up 3.3%, with positive growth mix offsetting volume declines, whilst logistics distribution fees declined 1.8%, a robust performance given the economic climate. Tobacco operating profits increased 3.3% and logistics operating profits decreased 3.8%, giving a combined growth at the Group level of 3%.

We continue to invest in the business to drive long-term growth whilst generating high margins of around 43%. And after tax, being charged at an effective rate of 24.5%, which remains our guidance for the full year, earnings per share grew by 5.1%.

In the EU, I'll start with the UK, where our financial performance benefited from a favorable comparative due to the timing of price increases. Revenues were up over 12%, and operating profit up more than 9%. In Germany, both revenues and profits were up over 3%. In Spain, revenues declined 4% and profits 2% as a result of further weakness in market volumes. In our rest of EU region, we grew revenues by 4% and profits by over 5%.

In the Americas and principally the U.S., our profits and revenues declined in a competitive market, partly impacted by shipment timings ahead of our price increase last year, whilst in our rest of world region, revenues increased by over 6% with profits up over 5%.

Volumes in Eastern Europe declined 9%, impacted by conditions in the Ukraine, where there was a distributor destocking and market softness following a tax increase. This was partially offset by growth in Russia. Eastern Europe remains a key strategic growth region for the group and we're continuing to invest to support our portfolio and strengthen our competitive position. We continue to make excellent progress in Asia Pacific, growing volumes over 4%, and gaining share in most of our key markets. Revenue increased 16%, benefiting from improved mix, and profits were up over 23%.

In Africa and the Middle East, we increased volumes, revenue and profit despite the impact of Syria, driven by a number of strong global and regional brand performances. In logistics, profits declined 3.8%, a robust result, given the difficult operating environment. In tobacco logistics, growth in cigars and fine-cut tobacco has helped offset the decline in cigarette volumes, while in other logistics, our transport operations performed well. We grew our market share in our Pharma division, and in our lottery business, we have added new point of sales to the network. Our ongoing cost savings program continues to focus on maximizing profitability.

Our average all-in cost of net debt was stable at 5.5%. W e expect this to be slightly higher at around 5.7% for the full year. The net interest charge is stable, given our normal first half working capital outflow, the final dividend payment, and buybacks. The appendices contain further details on our debt maturities.

Turning to the financing of the business, our closing adjusted net debt for this half was £9.9 billion. Working capital followed its normal pattern with a significant outflow in the first-half of just over £1 billion, due to a number of factors, including preproduction ahead of January and February duty increases. Net capital expenditure was £152 million, and our cash conversion declined as a result of the higher working capital outflow this half year. The impact of foreign exchange movements was minimal. As you've seen from the second quarter, there's strong sales momentum in the business and we want to maintain this over the long-term and we'll continue investing in our products, portfolio, our sales force, and other areas of the business to support our sales growth agenda.

As we've previously stated, we envisage net CapEx of around £400 million in 2012, reflecting our investment in capacity to meet demand in consumer growth segments and continue building our innovation pipeline. Our focus for the remainder of the year is to continue applying our sales growth drivers to further enhance sales and profit momentum.

This is supported by our work on key enablers, particularly when it comes to managing regulation and tackling illicit trade. We'll continue to vigorously challenge extreme regulatory proposals, such as plain packaging, which are not based on credible evidence, and will only serve to further fuel the illegal trade in tobacco. We expect the outcome of the court hearings in Australia to be announced later in the year and we'll make a comprehensive submission to the UK government for consultation.

From a footprint perspective, we expect EU consumers to remain focused on value, and we will be capitalizing on this dynamic with our total tobacco portfolio. In the UK, we expect further market volume declines and we'll continue to focus on reinforcing our leadership position. The market remains buoyant in Germany and we'll be seeking to capitalize on growth in fine cut tobacco and improve our cigarette share. Spain remains challenging, but as you see, we're improving our performance across our total tobacco portfolio.

Outside the EU, we see significant opportunities across our portfolio in value and in premium and above. And we'll build on the excellent results we have delivered through Davidoff, Gauloises Blonde, West and our luxury Cuban cigar portfolio. The U.S.A. remains challenging and highly competitive and our new management team are focused on improving the performance of our core brands through the sales growth drivers, with the benefit of critical mass from the combined cigarette and mass cigar business.
And finally, in logistics, we'll continue to identify opportunities to grow the business whilst maintaining our cost discipline.
Thank you. I'd like now to hand back to Alison.

We're generating momentum behind the top line through our strategic brands and total tobacco focus. You've seen that from our second quarter performance. And our priority is to drive sales further through our focus on the four sales growth drivers.

Our portfolio has never been in better shape. We've been very active across our brands and products and have a number of exciting initiatives in hand that will fuel further growth. One major development involves accelerating Davidoff sales. This will be launched in the second half and represents a key milestone in realizing Davidoff's global potential.

Our total tobacco portfolio combined with our focus on consumer-led innovation, gives Imperial unique opportunities. As well as driving growth of our key strategic brands, we'll be enhancing our fine cut tobacco performance and maximizing the growth potential of Habanos and our high-performance Snus business. The work we're doing in customer engagement and pricing is integral to our overall sales focus.

All four drivers need to work together to maximize returns and our people are embedding this approach across the business. It's the people at Imperial and the values they demonstrate that are making the difference, bringing our growth strategy to life on a daily basis throughout the organization. Their talent and their relentless focus on sales, costs and cash management gives me great confidence for the future.

The external environment is tough in some areas, but we've consistently demonstrated our ability to grow the business in this environment. We're generating good sales and profit momentum and the remainder of the year is all about building on this performance. The combination of our highly energized people and our unique total tobacco portfolio puts us in a strong position to maximize growth and further reward our shareholders. Thank you.
We'll now take any questions you may have. As usual, the presentation is being recorded, but please wait for a microphone, and give your name and organization before asking your question.

Good morning. Erik Bloomquist, Berenberg. Two questions. Firstly, the release in your comments indicated the Q2 might be indicative of the second half. Is that a fair interpretation of that statement and how do you think about the momentum in Q2 maintained into the second half?

And then second question is with respect to plain packaging in the UK. What do you expect out of the consultation and what kinds of actions do you – can you handicap the government is likely to take? Thank you.

Thank you. Okay. And the second question to get to plain packaging on price. The first question on Q2 I mean, clearly there is very strong momentum coming through in Q2. Volumes are only down very slightly. In fact, if you allow for the Syria lapping, they're actually up a bit, and 8% increase in revenues and clearly, that momentum we see coming through into the second half as well and that's very much in line with what we're seeing in terms of the overall market views on the numbers for the current year.

But also we're going to take the opportunity to invest. And if we do see growth coming through ahead of our expectations in terms of the top line, we're quite happy as well to see opportunities to further invest that in the business to drive further growth and into next year as well. So we'll be balancing that equation in terms of the growth momentum we see coming through in the second half.

On plain packs I thought I'd maybe take the opportunity for our newly-appointed Corporate Affairs Director to comment on that, particularly in relation to the UK consultation and really the business issue that we see that to be currently. Matt?

Thanks, morning. The easiest way to sort of to think about this is that the consultation only kicked off in the UK two weeks ago. So it's a bit early to be drawing any conclusions. I think we were slightly surprised by the tonality of some of the introductory comments. That's something that we have – we've taken up with the government separately. But the reality is that the consultation runs for another three months after which they will reflect on how they want to take the issue forward.

I think there have been – clearly in the meantime, there will be the results coming out of Australia which we expect in some time in the next six months potentially as early as July. That will inevitably, depending on which way it goes, influence some of the contributors to the debate. But then we've also had the EU commissioner come out in the last couple of weeks. I don't know if you've seen some of his comments, but basically saying that whilst packaging is important and is something that regulators need to look at, the EU is not interested in going as far as Australia is.

So the debate is going to happen for the next few months and it's going to be a prolonged period before we have clarity. And I think the other point just to bear in mind is that whichever way the Australian court case goes, the court case hinges on the constitution of Australia, and as it is going to everywhere else that this debate happens. And so therefore whether we're successful or whether we're unsuccessful in Australia doesn't actually read across to what's going to happen on a wider basis.

Okay. I think an important point for me as well, this is quite a significant business issue from a UK perspective, one I'm sure Glen is talking to the press about today as well because it's not really ultimately just about tobacco regulation. It's a wider consumer regulatory point, I think, and one that we're very engaged on. Who should be next? Just start at the end, David?

Hi. It's David Hayes from Nomura. Just firstly on Spain. In the last few days, we've seen some sort of price recessing by PMI and some others just for bringing back L&M, I guess particularly to parity with some of your value brands. I just wondered whether you're comfortable with that parity or whether you think this could potentially be a risk that this kind of – we saw last year sort of differentiation of brand positioning starts to become a bit of a theme?

And then secondly on the UK margins down 180 basis points in the half is that a trend or is there some one-off factors? I know you obviously talked about the shipment phasing. I just wondered whether that's an influence on that and whether that stabilizes here or whether we should have assume that margin in the UK keeps coming off and is offset by other margin performance elsewhere? Thanks.

Okay. I mean, maybe after Matt will (29:23) briefly comment as well. But I mean, Spain, I think all we're seeing at the moment is some tactical shift around – if you look at where the market now is in terms of the span of price points it covers, I think partly if you like, driven by us, there's now a lot more price points in the market. There's a lot more variety, a lot more opportunity to continue within terms of price points. I mentioned the Fortuna brand in my presentation and we now have that in the market, I think, in 24s, in various pack sizes, in various offerings for the consumer.

So you have got quite a different spectrum of price points in Spain than you would have seen, say two years ago, in the market, and opportunities for the consumer. But I see this as tactical. I don't know if there's anything you'd add after that (30:00) okay. It is just tactical at this point, I'd say.

That was Spain, then the other point was in relation to the UK margins. Very much, I see those coming back a bit more strongly in the second half. So yes, there are some factors that impacted it, but some – yeah, UK as we've always said is there or thereabouts that level of margin. We'll stick with those comments when we go (30:22).
Well, I started in 1996.

So yeah, we see a stronger H2 in terms of margins, but we are going to be there or thereabouts in terms of the UK margins. I think I said along to Chris and then we can go – keep going down the row to Jon.

Hi. It's Chris Wickham from Oriel. In terms of the fine cut shares that you disclosed, and obviously you're losing in the second quarter share in fewer markets than you were across the half as a whole. I was wondering if actually, you could give us a bit more detail on the competitive dynamics in fine cut and whether you're now on a sort of fight back to be able to keep any potential new entrants out of that market?

Let me split fine cut into its two key dynamics. One is in terms of roll-your-own and traditional roll-your-own brands. Yeah, you're very familiar with such as Golden Virginia and Drum and that aspect of the market. And those you know we've had some pressure on some of our shares for a while. We'll be, I think, for the first time in a while we've actually got Golden Virginia now growing in the UK. So even though you see some share pressure because of the growth in the market, we're doing very nicely with that brand in the UK in terms of overall volume growth currently.

So that's something we continue to address and there's a lot of initiatives in Roberto's area around Drum and Golden Virginia to say what are our other opportunities to move those brands back into stronger share growth. But the dynamic has been very strong for us and very strong for us over the last few years has been Make Your Own, and that's where we've seen significant growth. In fact, we've created segments in areas of Central Europe for Make Your Own as well. So therefore – as I said before, when you do create a segment, the only way the share is likely to go unfortunately is down to some degree because you start off with most of it and clearly, it's an attractive segment and there's competition in it.

And that links back to the point I was making around balancing those share and profit opportunities in a number of those markets. And we have taken some price decisions. But we also have got some very good share momentum. We've got some fantastic growth in Ducados, for example, in News, and in JPS Make Your Own across Europe. So it is a question of getting into the granularity a little bit in some of these segments. And as I said, apart from Poland, where we gained share but the market was significantly down, we did grow our overall volumes 3% in the first half. Jon?

Jon Leinster, UBS. A couple of questions. On the share repurchase, you said it was going to be £500 million going forward, is that a one year statement or is that a medium-term expectation? And secondly, on the U.S. business, I mean that's been sort of marginally disappointing or a bit disappointing, under pressure for a number of years. Does that remain a core business for the Group? Is there any real overlap with the rest of it? Or frankly, is it just turn around and maybe look at the options there?

Okay. Let me pick up on the buyback point and I'll give Arthur a two-second warning. But I think it would be useful just to talk around how we see the U.S. business currently shortly, after I've made some introductory comments.

On the buyback, I think I'm a bit reminded of the auction man who told his wife he loved her and then 50 years later, she said, do you still love me? You've not mentioned it for the last 50 years. And he said, I told you once. If I change my mind, I'll let you know. So buyback is our current statement. It's at £500 million and it'll continue at £500 million until we tell you otherwise. So that's where we are.

We are, as we said, consistently, to be slightly more helpful, in a balance sheet rebuild as well still. That's the buyback, we said that we were still going to do a bit of that while doing the £500 million buyback. And also clearly, we've got the increase in dividend growth trajectory as well. Don't get carried away, like one of the press did, that 13% was some indication. It's clearly a third of our last year's full-year dividend. As we've indicated, it's formulaic for the first half.

On the U.S., we've been very transparent about it. It is a difficult market for us. It has been for a while. And I think looking at some of the releases from some of our competition in the market, they're also finding it quite tough currently, too. But we've got a new management team in there. We've got a lot going on keying into the sales growth drivers, and maybe, Arthur, you could just give a bit more flavor to what's happening in that business.

Yes, indeed. Results to-date have obviously been not satisfactory, satisfactory at all. What we do is also not a surprise. We do have new management in place. We do believe that the critical mass that we will achieve from combining mass cigars with cigarettes is going to be an advantage for us in the marketplace, as well as in the strategy development going forward.

And we're working very hard on a number of key things to improve the performance of that business, which we need to give time to actually work, one of which is a state-by-state pricing strategy, which we think is going to give us the right competitive set of our brands versus the competition. We're moving quickly to actually change our strategy from being wholesale-focused to be retail-focused and we have a number of portfolio innovation plans ahead of us, which – all three of which are going to help us to actually move that business forward, which is going to give us the time that it needs to actually start getting onto a positive trajectory.
Thank you. Okay. Next? Next row back now as you work along?

Yes. Good morning. This is Fulvio Cazzol from Goldman Sachs. I was just wondering on the working capital, I know you highlighted the timing of excise impacting the production in the first half. I was just wondering how much of the increase in working capital is structural i.e. to support new innovation capsules, the new packaging and so forth.
And secondly, I was wondering if you can give us an update on illicit trading in Spain whether that's moved materially since you last updated us? Thank you.

I'll pick up the working capital. Yeah. Indeed. In fact, as we said, basically cash conversion is an important metric for us and it was impacted this year effectively by a working capital swing. To an extent, working capitals are coming from normal levels. If we take a look at last year, the year to March 2011 and I think it's necessary to look at working capital over a 12-month period, because it picks up the business cycle in terms of what's happening. We had a very strong performance in the 12 months to March 2011, which benefited 2011 results. And as working capital has come back to a more normal level in 2012. Effectively, that's adversely affected the first half result.

If I take a look, and it's probably better looking at the absolute level of working capital. If I take a look at the absolute level of working capital at March 2012, despite the passage of two years, it's at the same level it was in March 2010, so there isn't a massive structural change. There will inevitably be small changes to working capital, the growth agenda. Interestingly enough, it's not so much to do with the innovation and that coming through, I mean, that's generally – that comes through with an increase in our capital spend, that we're talking about £400 million of CapEx this year to support that. And some people say that it's not really machinery, it's actually off of consumables because a fully loaded make pack complex will pay back itself in terms of the margin it generates over a very short period of time, often in less than a year.

But, so but the – where there will be some, and a minimal working capital movement is obviously as our customers in those countries where we'd offer it through distributors were actually selling more. Maybe their credit limits go up a little, but it's not significant in the scheme of things. And we do expect the – currently expect the first half working capital to unwind, as it has done in previous years, by the year-end.

And some of the illicit trade in Spain, I mean, there's always still hard numbers to get your head around. But we're still very much at the sort of the high single digit level in terms of penetration of the Spanish market. Clearly, that's a lot higher in Southern parts of Spain. So this is a key aspect for us still in our discussions and debates with government.

As part of that pricing sales growth driver, excise strategy is really important within that. And clearly, in the excise, similar like Spain, particularly, the impacts that can have on illicit trade is really key. So even though we've had a price increase recently with excise, actually, the bottom of the market hasn't moved up too much, which I think is quite helpful from a consumer perspective and the range of prices offered to consumers in the market. And clearly also, the fine-cut aspect, too.
Who's going next, going on the row? Yeah.

Thanks. Hi, good morning. James Bushnell from Exane BNP Paribas. Two questions, please. Firstly, just going back on the question on sales growth. You mentioned if the full-year sales growth was above your expectations, you may choose to reinvest. Would you be able to tell us what your full-year expectations are? And question two, on Australia, taking the hypothesis that plain packaging happens in December, do you think that's likely to change the profit growth trajectory in that market? And if so, how? Thanks.

Well, in terms of the first point, clearly, we've given the rules and everything else. We don't give out explicit numbers in terms of forecasts. Clearly, if we're uncomfortable with where the market's sitting, we need to say something. So that's the answer to your first question.
